# no-worker

import ltk

tutorial = ltk.Tutorial([
(
    "#I1",
    "click",
    ltk.VBox(
        ltk.Heading2("PySheets Tutorial: Chess ‚ôüÔ∏è"),
        ltk.Text("""
        	In this tutorial we will show an advanced feature of PySheets:
            interacting with the spreadsheet from a Python cell functions.
            Because PySheets is entirely written in Python and the cell functions
            run locally in the browser, cell functions can "escape" to the main
            UI and do interesting things.
        """),
        ltk.Text("""
        	In this example, the Python code in I1 loads the PyPI package
            called "chess", creates a board, and then finds the cells in the main
            spreadsheet to replace them with images of Chess pieces.
            Then, I1 registers event handlers so you can play a game of chess
            against the Python code in I1. No AI is used for the game logic,
            but that would be possible as well.
        """),
        ltk.Text("""
        	To make a move, click on a white piece. Then click where you want to move it.
        """),
        ltk.Break(),
        ltk.Text("Next step:"),
        ltk.Text("‚û°Ô∏è Click inside cell I1 to see the code."),
    ),
),(
    "#H4",
    "click",
    ltk.VBox(
        ltk.Text("""
        	This ends the tutorial on UI integration. 
            By now, you have a good idea how powerful the cell functions are.
            There is no limit to what you can do. Examples are injecting new CSS,
            injecting new JavaScript, downloading data, add menu functions, 
            and changing anything in the PySheets UI.
        """),
        ltk.Break(),
        ltk.Text("""
        	For fun, check out cell I10. It contains the source for this tutorial.
            It runs as a cell function and changes the experience of PySheets from
            within the sheet. PySheet is not running the tutorial, but the actual
            sheet is running it itself.
        """),
        ltk.Break(),
        ltk.Text("Next steps:"),
        ltk.Link(
            "https://github.com/PySheets/pysheets?tab=readme-ov-file#tutorials", 
            "‚û°Ô∏è All PySheets Tutorials"
        ).css("text-decoration", "none"),
    ),
)])

ltk.schedule(tutorial.show, "Start a bit later", 0.1)

"Tutorial üéì"
